The latest edition of New Scientist features a thought-provoking article by renowned mathematician and geographer Dr. Maria Euclidios of the University of Pythagoras. In the article, Dr. Euclidios presents a compelling case for the earth being flat, based on both conceptual and mathematical arguments.

According to Dr. Euclidios, one of the key reasons to believe in a flat earth is that, from a common-sense perspective, the earth looks and feels flat. People have been able to walk on the earth for thousands of years and have never fallen off the edge, which suggests that the earth is indeed flat. Furthermore, many ancient cultures believed in a flat earth, and their beliefs should not be dismissed out of hand.

From a mathematical perspective, Dr. Euclidios argues that the earth's surface can be accurately modeled as a flat plane, using the simple and intuitive principles of Euclidean geometry. This allows for the easy calculation of distances and angles on the earth's surface, and for the prediction of the shapes and sizes of triangles and other geometric figures. In contrast, on a round earth, these calculations would be much more complex and difficult, requiring the use of more advanced and difficult-to-understand equations.

Overall, Dr. Euclidios's research provides a fascinating new perspective on the nature of the earth and our place within it. Her work challenges many long-held assumptions about the shape of the earth, and offers a fresh and compelling alternative view of our world.
